title: Biodiversity
content: The number of species that are known and described range between 1.7-1.8 million. This refers to biodiversity or the number and types of organisms present on earth.

title: Nomenclature
content: Hence, there is a need to standardise the naming of living organisms such that a particular organism is known by the same name all over the world. This process is called nomenclature.

title: Identification
content: Obviously, nomenclature or naming is only possible when the organism is described correctly and we know to what organism the name is attached to. This is identification.

title: Binomial nomenclature
content: Each name has two components – the Generic name and the specific epithet. This system of providing a name with two components is called Binomial nomenclature.

title: Classification
content: Since it is nearly impossible to study all the living organisms, it is necessary to devise some means to make this possible. This process is classification. Classification is the process by which anything is grouped into convenient categories based on some easily observable characters.

title: Taxa
content: The scientific term for these categories is taxa. Here you must recognise that taxa can indicate categories at very different levels.

title: Taxonomy
content: Hence, based on characteristics, all living organisms can be classified into different taxa. This process of classification is taxonomy.

title: Systematics
content: Human beings were, since long, not only interested in knowing more about different kinds of organisms and their diversities, but also the relationships among them. This branch of study was referred to as systematics. The word systematics is derived from the Latin word ‘systema’ which means systematic arrangement of organisms.

title: Taxonomic Category
content: Classification is not a single step process but involves hierarchy of steps in which each step represents a rank or category. Since the category is a part of overall taxonomic arrangement, it is called the taxonomic category and all categories together constitute the taxonomic hierarchy.

title: Taxon
content: Each category, referred to as a unit of classification, in fact, represents a rank and is commonly termed as taxon (pl.: taxa).

title: Species
content: Taxonomic studies consider a group of individual organisms with fundamental similarities as a species.

title: Genus
content: Genus comprises a group of related species which has more characters in common in comparison to species of other genera. We can say that genera are aggregates of closely related species.

title: Family
content: The next category, Family, has a group of related genera with still less number of similarities as compared to genus and species.

title: Order
content: Order being a higher category, is the assemblage of families which exhibit a few similar characters.

title: Class
content: This category includes related orders.

title: Phylum
content: Classes comprising animals like fishes, amphibians, reptiles, birds along with mammals constitute the next higher category called Phylum. All these, based on the common features like presence of notochord and dorsal hollow neural system, are included in phylum Chordata. In case of plants, classes with a few similar characters are assigned to a higher category called Division.

title: Kingdom
content: All animals belonging to various phyla are assigned to the highest category called Kingdom Animalia in the classification system of animals. The Kingdom Plantae, on the other hand, is distinct, and comprises all plants from various divisions. Henceforth, we will refer to these two groups as animal and plant kingdoms.

title: Taxonomy
content: In order to facilitate the study of kinds and diversity of organisms, biologists have evolved certain rules and principles for identification, nomenclature and classification of organisms. The branch of knowledge dealing with these aspects is referred to as taxonomy.

title: Five Kingdom Classification
content: R.H. Whittaker (1969) proposed a Five Kingdom Classification. The kingdoms defined by him were named Monera, Protista, Fungi, Plantae and Animalia.

title: Kingdom Monera
content: Bacteria are the sole members of the Kingdom Monera.

title: Coccus (pl.: cocci)
content: the spherical Coccus (pl.: cocci)

title: Bacillus (pl.: bacilli)
content: the rod-shaped Bacillus (pl.: bacilli)

title: Vibrium (pl.: vibrio)
content: the comma-shaped Vibrium (pl.: vibrio)

title: Spirillum (pl.: spirilla)
content: and the spiral Spirillum (pl.: spirilla)

title: Autotrophic bacteria
content: Some of the bacteria are autotrophic, i.e., they synthesise their own food from inorganic substrates. They may be photosynthetic autotrophic or chemosynthetic autotrophic.

title: Heterotrophic bacteria
content: The vast majority of bacteria are heterotrophs, i.e., they depend on other organisms or on dead organic matter for food.

title: Archaebacteria
content: These bacteria are special since they live in some of the most harsh habitats such as extreme salty areas (halophiles), hot springs (thermoacidophiles) and marshy areas (methanogens). Archaebacteria differ from other bacteria in having a different cell wall structure and this feature is responsible for their survival in extreme conditions.

title: Methanogens
content: Methanogens are present in the gut of several ruminant animals such as cows and buffaloes and they are responsible for the production of methane (biogas) from the dung of these animals.

title: Eubacteria
content: There are thousands of different eubacteria or ‘true bacteria’. They are characterised by the presence of a rigid cell wall, and if motile, a flagellum.

title: Cyanobacteria
content: The cyanobacteria (also referred to as blue-green algae) have chlorophyll a similar to green plants and are photosynthetic autotrophs.

title: Heterocysts
content: Some of these organisms can fix atmospheric nitrogen in specialised cells called heterocysts, e.g., Nostoc and Anabaena.

title: Mycoplasma
content: The Mycoplasma are organisms that completely lack a cell wall. They are the smallest living cells known and can survive without oxygen. Many mycoplasma are pathogenic in animals and plants.

title: Kingdom Protista
content: All single-celled eukaryotes are placed under Protista, but the boundaries of this kingdom are not well defined.

title: Chrysophytes
content: This group includes diatoms and golden algae (desmids).

title: Diatomaceous earth
content: Thus, diatoms have left behind large amount of cell wall deposits in their habitat; this accumulation over billions of years is referred to as ‘diatomaceous earth’.

title: Dinoflagellates
content: These organisms are mostly marine and photosynthetic.

title: Red tides
content: Very often, red dinoflagellates (Example: Gonyaulax) undergo such rapid multiplication that they make the sea appear red (red tides).

title: Euglenoids
content: Majority of them are fresh water organisms found in stagnant water. Instead of a cell wall, they have a protein rich layer called pellicle which makes their body flexible.

title: Pellicle
content: Instead of a cell wall, they have a protein rich layer called pellicle which makes their body flexible.

title: Slime Moulds
content: Slime moulds are saprophytic protists. The body moves along decaying twigs and leaves engulfing organic material.

title: Plasmodium (slime moulds)
content: Under suitable conditions, they form an aggregation called plasmodium which may grow and spread over several feet.

title: Protozoans
content: All protozoans are heterotrophs and live as predators or parasites. They are believed to be primitive relatives of animals.

title: Amoeboid protozoans
content: These organisms live in fresh water, sea water or moist soil. They move and capture their prey by putting out pseudopodia (false feet) as in Amoeba.

title: Flagellated protozoans
content: The members of this group are either free-living or parasitic. They have flagella.

title: Ciliated protozoans
content: These are aquatic, actively moving organisms because of the presence of thousands of cilia. They have a cavity (gullet) that opens to the outside of the cell surface.

title: Sporozoans
content: This includes diverse organisms that have an infectious spore-like stage in their life cycle.

title: Kingdom Fungi
content: The fungi constitute a unique kingdom of heterotrophic organisms. They show a great diversity in morphology and habitat.

title: Hyphae
content: Their bodies consist of long, slender thread-like structures called hyphae.

title: Mycelium
content: The network of hyphae is known as mycelium.

title: Coenocytic hyphae
content: Some hyphae are continuous tubes filled with multinucleated cytoplasm – these are called coenocytic hyphae.

title: Saprophytes (fungi)
content: Most fungi are heterotrophic and absorb soluble organic matter from dead substrates and hence are called saprophytes.

title: Parasites (fungi)
content: Those that depend on living plants and animals are called parasites.

title: Symbionts (fungi)
content: They can also live as symbionts – in association with algae as lichens and with roots of higher plants as mycorrhiza.

title: Plasmogamy
content: Fusion of protoplasms between two motile or non-motile gametes called plasmogamy.

title: Karyogamy
content: Fusion of two nuclei called karyogamy.

title: Dikaryophase
content: However, in other fungi (ascomycetes and basidiomycetes), an intervening dikaryotic stage (n + n, i.e., two nuclei per cell) occurs; such a condition is called a dikaryon and the phase is called dikaryophase of fungus.

title: Phycomycetes
content: Members of phycomycetes are found in aquatic habitats and on decaying wood in moist and damp places or as obligate parasites on plants. The mycelium is aseptate and coenocytic.

title: Ascomycetes
content: Commonly known as sac-fungi, the ascomycetes are mostly multicellular, e.g., Penicillium, or rarely unicellular, e.g., yeast (Saccharomyces).

title: Conidia
content: The asexual spores are conidia produced exogenously on the special mycelium called conidiophores.

title: Ascospores
content: Sexual spores are called ascospores which are produced endogenously in sac like asci (singular ascus).

title: Ascocarps
content: These asci are arranged in different types of fruiting bodies called ascocarps.

title: Basidiomycetes
content: Commonly known forms of basidiomycetes are mushrooms, bracket fungi or puffballs.

title: Basidiospores
content: Karyogamy and meiosis take place in the basidium producing four basidiospores. The basidiospores are exogenously produced on the basidium (pl.: basidia).

title: Basidiocarps
content: The basidia are arranged in fruiting bodies called basidiocarps.

title: Deuteromycetes
content: Commonly known as imperfect fungi because only the asexual or vegetative phases of these fungi are known.

title: Kingdom Plantae
content: Kingdom Plantae includes all eukaryotic chlorophyll-containing organisms commonly called plants.

title: Alternation of generations
content: Life cycle of plants has two distinct phases – the diploid sporophytic and the haploid gametophytic – that alternate with each other. The lengths of the haploid and diploid phases, and whether these phases are free living or dependent on others, vary among different groups in plants. This phenomenon is called alternation of generations.

title: Kingdom Animalia
content: This kingdom is characterised by heterotrophic eukaryotic organisms that are multicellular and their cells lack cell walls.

title: Viruses
content: The viruses are non-cellular organisms that are characterised by having an inert crystalline structure outside the living cell. Once they infect a cell, they take over the machinery of the host cell to replicate themselves, killing the host.

title: Contagium vivum fluidum
content: M.W. Beijerinck (1898) demonstrated that the extract of the infected plants of tobacco could cause infection in healthy plants and named the new pathogen “virus” and called the fluid as Contagium vivum fluidum (infectious living fluid).

title: Bacteriophages
content: Bacterial viruses or bacteriophages (viruses that infect the bacteria) are usually double stranded DNA viruses.

title: Capsid
content: The protein coat called capsid made of small subunits called capsomeres, protects the nucleic acid.

title: Capsomeres
content: The protein coat called capsid made of small subunits called capsomeres, protects the nucleic acid.

title: Viroids
content: In 1971, T.O. Diener discovered a new infectious agent that was smaller than viruses and caused potato spindle tuber disease. It was found to be a free RNA; it lacked the protein coat that is found in viruses, hence the name viroid.

title: Prions
content: In modern medicine certain infectious neurological diseases were found to be transmitted by an agent consisting of abnormally folded protein. The agent was similar in size to viruses. These agents were called prions.

title: Lichens
content: Lichens are symbiotic associations i.e. mutually useful associations, between algae and fungi.

title: Phycobiont
content: The algal component is known as phycobiont and fungal component as mycobiont, which are autotrophic and heterotrophic, respectively.

title: Mycobiont
content: The algal component is known as phycobiont and fungal component as mycobiont, which are autotrophic and heterotrophic, respectively.

title: Artificial classification systems
content: The earliest systems of classification used only gross superficial morphological characters such as habit, colour, number and shape of leaves, etc. They were based mainly on vegetative characters or on the androecium structure (system given by Linnaeus). Such systems were artificial; they separated the closely related species since they were based on a few characteristics. Also, the artificial systems gave equal weightage to vegetative and sexual characteristics; this is not acceptable since we know that often the vegetative characters are more easily affected by environment.

title: Natural classification systems
content: As against this, natural classification systems developed, which were based on natural affinities among the organisms and consider, not only the external features, but also internal features, like ultrastructure, anatomy, embryology and phytochemistry. Such a classification for flowering plants was given by George Bentham and Joseph Dalton Hooker.

title: Phylogenetic classification systems
content: At present phylogenetic classification systems based on evolutionary relationships between the various organisms are acceptable. This assumes that organisms belonging to the same taxa have a common ancestor.

title: Numerical Taxonomy
content: Numerical Taxonomy which is now easily carried out using computers is based on all observable characteristics. Number and codes are assigned to all the characters and the data are then processed. In this way each character is given equal importance and at the same time hundreds of characters can be considered.

title: Cytotaxonomy
content: Cytotaxonomy, that is based on cytological information like chromosome number, structure, behaviour and chemotaxonomy, that uses the chemical constituents of the plant to resolve confusions, are also used by taxonomists these days.

title: Chemotaxonomy
content: Cytotaxonomy, that is based on cytological information like chromosome number, structure, behaviour and chemotaxonomy, that uses the chemical constituents of the plant to resolve confusions, are also used by taxonomists these days.

title: Algae
content: Algae are chlorophyll-bearing, simple, thalloid, autotrophic and largely aquatic (both fresh water and marine) organisms.

title: Isogamous (algae)
content: These gametes can be flagellated and similar in size (as in Ulothrix) or non-flagellated (non-motile) but similar in size (as in Spirogyra). Such reproduction is called isogamous.

title: Anisogamous (algae)
content: Fusion of two gametes dissimilar in size, as in species of Eudorina is termed as anisogamous.

title: Oogamous (algae)
content: Fusion between one large, non-motile (static) female gamete and a smaller, motile male gamete is termed oogamous, e.g., Volvox, Fucus.

title: Hydrocolloids
content: Certain marine brown and red algae produce large amounts of hydrocolloids (water holding substances), e.g., algin (brown algae) and carrageen (red algae) which are used commercially.

title: Chlorophyceae (Green Algae)
content: The members of chlorophyceae are commonly called green algae. The plant body may be unicellular, colonial or filamentous.

title: Pyrenoids
content: Most of the members have one or more storage bodies called pyrenoids located in the chloroplasts. Pyrenoids contain protein besides starch.

title: Phaeophyceae (Brown Algae)
content: The members of phaeophyceae or brown algae are found primarily in marine habitats. They show great variation in size and form.

title: Holdfast
content: The plant body is usually attached to the substratum by a holdfast, and has a stalk, the stipe and leaf like photosynthetic organ – the frond.

title: Stipe
content: The plant body is usually attached to the substratum by a holdfast, and has a stalk, the stipe and leaf like photosynthetic organ – the frond.

title: Frond
content: The plant body is usually attached to the substratum by a holdfast, and has a stalk, the stipe and leaf like photosynthetic organ – the frond.

title: Rhodophyceae (Red Algae)
content: The members of rhodophyceae are commonly called red algae because of the predominance of the red pigment, r-phycoerythrin in their body.

title: Bryophytes
content: Bryophytes include the various mosses and liverworts that are found commonly growing in moist shaded areas in the hills.

title: Amphibians of the plant kingdom
content: Bryophytes are also called amphibians of the plant kingdom because these plants can live in soil but are dependent on water for sexual reproduction.

title: Gametophyte (bryophytes)
content: The main plant body of the bryophyte is haploid. It produces gametes, hence is called a gametophyte.

title: Antheridium
content: The male sex organ is called antheridium. They produce biflagellate antherozoids.

title: Archegonium
content: The female sex organ called archegonium is flask-shaped and produces a single egg.

title: Sporophyte (bryophytes)
content: Zygotes do not undergo reduction division immediately. They produce a multicellular body called a sporophyte.

title: Liverworts
content: The liverworts grow usually in moist, shady habitats such as banks of streams, marshy ground, damp soil, bark of trees and deep in the woods. The plant body of a liverwort is thalloid, e.g., Marchantia.

title: Gemmae
content: Asexual reproduction in liverworts takes place by fragmentation of thalli, or by the formation of specialised structures called gemmae (sing. gemma). Gemmae are green, multicellular, asexual buds, which develop in small receptacles called gemma cups located on the thalli.

title: Mosses
content: The predominant stage of the life cycle of a moss is the gametophyte which consists of two stages. The first stage is the protonema stage, which develops directly from a spore. It is a creeping, green, branched and frequently filamentous stage. The second stage is the leafy stage, which develops from the secondary protonema as a lateral bud.

title: Pteridophytes
content: The Pteridophytes include horsetails and ferns. Pteridophytes are used for medicinal purposes and as soil-binders. They are also frequently grown as ornamentals. Evolutionarily, they are the first terrestrial plants to possess vascular tissues – xylem and phloem.

title: Microphylls
content: The leaves in pteridophyta are small (microphylls) as in Selaginella or large (macrophylls) as in ferns.

title: Macrophylls
content: The leaves in pteridophyta are small (microphylls) as in Selaginella or large (macrophylls) as in ferns.

title: Sporophylls
content: The sporophytes bear sporangia that are subtended by leaf-like appendages called sporophylls.

title: Strobili or cones (Pteridophytes)
content: In some cases sporophylls may form distinct compact structures called strobili or cones (Selaginella, Equisetum).

title: Prothallus
content: The spores germinate to give rise to inconspicuous, small but multicellular, free-living, mostly photosynthetic thalloid gametophytes called prothallus.

title: Homosporous
content: In majority of the pteridophytes all the spores are of similar kinds; such plants are called homosporous.

title: Heterosporous (Pteridophytes)
content: Genera like Selaginella and Salvinia which produce two kinds of spores, macro (large) and micro (small) spores, are known as heterosporous.

title: Gymnosperms
content: The gymnosperms (gymnos : naked, sperma : seeds) are plants in which the ovules are not enclosed by any ovary wall and remain exposed, both before and after fertilisation. The seeds that develop post-fertilisation, are not covered, i.e., are naked.

title: Coralloid roots
content: Roots in some genera have fungal association in the form of mycorrhiza (Pinus), while in some others (Cycas) small specialised roots called coralloid roots are associated with N2- fixing cyanobacteria.

title: Microsporangiate or male strobili
content: The strobili bearing microsporophylls and microsporangia are called microsporangiate or male strobili.

title: Pollen grain (Gymnosperms)
content: The microspores develop into a male gametophytic generation which is highly reduced and is confined to only a limited number of cells. This reduced gametophyte is called a pollen grain.

title: Macrosporangiate or female strobili
content: The cones bearing megasporophylls with ovules or megasporangia are called macrosporangiate or female strobili.

title: Angiosperms
content: Unlike the gymnosperms where the ovules are naked, in the angiosperms or flowering plants, the pollen grains and ovules are developed in specialised structures called flowers. In angiosperms, the seeds are enclosed in fruits.

title: Cellular level of organisation
content: In sponges, the cells are arranged as loose cell aggregates, i.e., they exhibit cellular level of organisation. Some division of labour (activities) occur among the cells.

title: Tissue level of organisation
content: In coelenterates, the arrangement of cells is more complex. Here the cells performing the same function are arranged into tissues, hence is called tissue level of organisation.

title: Organ level of organisation
content: A still higher level of organisation, i.e., organ level is exhibited by members of Platyhelminthes and other higher phyla where tissues are grouped together to form organs, each specialised for a particular function.

title: Organ system level of organisation
content: In animals like Annelids, Arthropods, Molluscs, Echinoderms and Chordates, organs have associated to form functional systems, each system concerned with a specific physiological function. This pattern is called organ system level of organisation.

title: Incomplete digestive system
content: For example, the digestive system in Platyhelminthes has only a single opening to the outside of the body that serves as both mouth and anus, and is hence called incomplete.

title: Complete digestive system
content: A complete digestive system has two openings, mouth and anus.

title: Open circulatory system
content: (i) open type in which the blood is pumped out of the heart and the cells and tissues are directly bathed in it

title: Closed circulatory system
content: (ii) closed type in which the blood is circulated through a series of vessels of varying diameters (arteries, veins and capillaries).

title: Asymmetrical
content: Sponges are mostly asymmetrical, i.e., any plane that passes through the centre does not divide them into equal halves.

title: Radial symmetry
content: When any plane passing through the central axis of the body divides the organism into two identical halves, it is called radial symmetry.

title: Bilateral symmetry
content: Animals like annelids, arthropods, etc., where the body can be divided into identical left and right halves in only one plane, exhibit bilateral symmetry.

title: Diploblastic animals
content: Animals in which the cells are arranged in two embryonic layers, an external ectoderm and an internal endoderm, are called diploblastic animals, e.g., coelenterates.

title: Mesoglea
content: An undifferentiated layer, mesoglea, is present in between the ectoderm and the endoderm.

title: Triploblastic animals
content: Those animals in which the developing embryo has a third germinal layer, mesoderm, in between the ectoderm and endoderm, are called triploblastic animals (platyhelminthes to chordates, Figure 4.2b).

title: Coelom
content: The body cavity, which is lined by mesoderm is called coelom. Animals possessing coelom are called coelomates, e.g., annelids, molluscs, arthropods, echinoderms, hemichordates and chordates.

title: Coelomates
content: Animals possessing coelom are called coelomates, e.g., annelids, molluscs, arthropods, echinoderms, hemichordates and chordates.

title: Pseudocoelom
content: In some animals, the body cavity is not lined by mesoderm, instead, the mesoderm is present as scattered pouches in between the ectoderm and endoderm. Such a body cavity is called pseudocoelom and the animals possessing them are called pseudocoelomates, e.g., aschelminthes.

title: Pseudocoelomates
content: In some animals, the body cavity is not lined by mesoderm, instead, the mesoderm is present as scattered pouches in between the ectoderm and endoderm. Such a body cavity is called pseudocoelom and the animals possessing them are called pseudocoelomates, e.g., aschelminthes.

title: Acoelomates
content: The animals in which the body cavity is absent are called acoelomates, e.g., platyhelminthes.

title: Metameric segmentation (Metamerism)
content: In some animals, the body is externally and internally divided into segments with a serial repetition of at least some organs. For example, in earthworm, the body shows this pattern called metameric segmentation and the phenomenon is known as metamerism.

title: Notochord
content: Notochord is a mesodermally derived rod-like structure formed on the dorsal side during embryonic development in some animals.

title: Chordates
content: Animals with notochord are called chordates and those animals which do not form this structure are called non-chordates, e.g., porifera to echinoderms.

title: Non-chordates
content: Animals with notochord are called chordates and those animals which do not form this structure are called non-chordates, e.g., porifera to echinoderms.

title: Porifera (Sponges)
content: Members of this phylum are commonly known as sponges. They are generally marine and mostly asymmetrical animals. These are primitive multicellular animals and have cellular level of organisation.

title: Water transport or canal system
content: Sponges have a water transport or canal system. Water enters through minute pores (ostia) in the body wall into a central cavity, spongocoel, from where it goes out through the osculum. This pathway of water transport is helpful in food gathering, respiratory exchange and removal of waste.

title: Ostia
content: Water enters through minute pores (ostia) in the body wall into a central cavity, spongocoel

title: Spongocoel
content: Water enters through minute pores (ostia) in the body wall into a central cavity, spongocoel, from where it goes out through the osculum.

title: Osculum
content: Water enters through minute pores (ostia) in the body wall into a central cavity, spongocoel, from where it goes out through the osculum.

title: Choanocytes or collar cells
content: Choanocytes or collar cells line the spongocoel and the canals.

title: Coelenterata (Cnidaria)
content: They are aquatic, mostly marine, sessile or free-swimming, radially symmetrical animals. The name cnidaria is derived from the cnidoblasts or cnidocytes (which contain the stinging capsules or nematocysts) present on the tentacles and the body.

title: Cnidoblasts or cnidocytes
content: The name cnidaria is derived from the cnidoblasts or cnidocytes (which contain the stinging capsules or nematocysts) present on the tentacles and the body.

title: Nematocysts
content: The name cnidaria is derived from the cnidoblasts or cnidocytes (which contain the stinging capsules or nematocysts) present on the tentacles and the body.

title: Polyp
content: Cnidarians exhibit two basic body forms called polyp and medusa. The former is a sessile and cylindrical form like Hydra, Adamsia, etc.

title: Medusa
content: Cnidarians exhibit two basic body forms called polyp and medusa. The latter is umbrella-shaped and free-swimming like Aurelia or jelly fish.

title: Metagenesis (Coelenterata)
content: Those cnidarians which exist in both forms exhibit alternation of generations (Metagenesis), i.e., polyps produce medusae asexually and medusae form the polyps sexually (e.g., Obelia).

title: Ctenophores (Sea walnuts or comb jellies)
content: Ctenophores, commonly known as sea walnuts or comb jellies are exclusively marine, radially symmetrical, diploblastic organisms with tissue level of organisation.

title: Bioluminescence
content: Bioluminescence (the property of a living organism to emit light) is well-marked in ctenophores.

title: Platyhelminthes (Flatworms)
content: They have dorso-ventrally flattened body, hence are called flatworms. These are mostly endoparasites found in animals including human beings.

title: Flame cells
content: Specialised cells called flame cells help in osmoregulation and excretion.

title: Aschelminthes (Roundworms)
content: The body of the aschelminthes is circular in cross-section, hence, the name roundworms. They may be freeliving, aquatic and terrestrial or parasitic in plants and animals.

title: Annelida
content: Their body surface is distinctly marked out into segments or metameres and, hence, the phylum name Annelida (Latin, annulus : little ring).

title: Parapodia
content: Aquatic annelids like Nereis possess lateral appendages, parapodia, which help in swimming.

title: Nephridia
content: Nephridia (sing. nephridium) help in osmoregulation and excretion.

title: Arthropoda
content: This is the largest phylum of Animalia which includes insects. Over two-thirds of all named species on earth are arthropods.

title: Malpighian tubules
content: Excretion takes place through malpighian tubules.

title: Mollusca
content: This is the second largest animal phylum. Molluscs are terrestrial or aquatic (marine or fresh water) having an organ-system level of organisation.

title: Mantle
content: A soft and spongy layer of skin forms a mantle over the visceral hump.

title: Mantle cavity
content: The space between the hump and the mantle is called the mantle cavity in which feather like gills are present.

title: Radula
content: The mouth contains a file-like rasping organ for feeding, called radula.

title: Echinodermata
content: These animals have an endoskeleton of calcareous ossicles and, hence, the name Echinodermata (Spiny bodied).

title: Water vascular system
content: The most distinctive feature of echinoderms is the presence of water vascular system which helps in locomotion, capture and transport of food and respiration.

title: Hemichordata
content: Hemichordata was earlier considered as a sub-phylum under phylum Chordata. But now it is placed as a separate phylum under non-chordata. Hemichordates have a rudimentary structure in the collar region called stomochord, a structure similar to notochord.

title: Stomochord
content: Hemichordates have a rudimentary structure in the collar region called stomochord, a structure similar to notochord.

title: Chordata
content: Animals belonging to phylum Chordata are fundamentally characterised by the presence of a notochord, a dorsal hollow nerve cord and paired pharyngeal gill slits.

title: Protochordates
content: Subphyla Urochordata and Cephalochordata are often referred to as protochordates and are exclusively marine.

title: Urochordata (Tunicata)
content: In Urochordata, notochord is present only in larval tail

title: Cephalochordata
content: in Cephalochordata, it extends from head to tail region and is persistent throughout their life.

title: Vertebrata
content: The members of subphylum Vertebrata possess notochord during the embryonic period. The notochord is replaced by a cartilaginous or bony vertebral column in the adult. Thus all vertebrates are chordates but all chordates are not vertebrates.

title: Cyclostomata
content: All living members of the class Cyclostomata are ectoparasites on some fishes. They have an elongated body bearing 6-15 pairs of gill slits for respiration. Cyclostomes have a sucking and circular mouth without jaws.

title: Chondrichthyes
content: They are marine animals with streamlined body and have cartilaginous endoskeleton. Mouth is located ventrally. Notochord is persistent throughout life. Gill slits are separate and without operculum (gill cover). The skin is tough, containing minute placoid scales.

title: Poikilothermous (cold-blooded)
content: They are cold-blooded (poikilothermous) animals, i.e., they lack the capacity to regulate their body temperature.

title: Osteichthyes
content: It includes both marine and fresh water fishes with bony endoskeleton. Their body is streamlined. Mouth is mostly terminal. They have four pairs of gills which are covered by an operculum on each side. Skin is covered with cycloid/ctenoid scales. Air bladder is present which regulates buoyancy. Heart is two-chambered (one auricle and one ventricle). They are cold-blooded animals. Sexes are separate. Fertilisation is usually external. They are mostly oviparous and development is direct.

title: Amphibia
content: As the name indicates (Gr., Amphi : dual, bios, life), amphibians can live in aquatic as well as terrestrial habitats. Most of them have two pairs of limbs. Body is divisible into head and trunk. Tail may be present in some. The amphibian skin is moist (without scales). The eyes have eyelids. A tympanum represents the ear. Alimentary canal, urinary and reproductive tracts open into a common chamber called cloaca which opens to the exterior. Respiration is by gills, lungs and through skin. The heart is three-chambered (two auricles and one ventricle). These are cold-blooded animals. Sexes are separate. Fertilisation is external. They are oviparous and development is indirect.

title: Reptilia
content: The class name refers to their creeping or crawling mode of locomotion (Latin, repere or reptum, to creep or crawl). They are mostly terrestrial animals and their body is covered by dry and cornified skin, epidermal scales or scutes. They do not have external ear openings. Tympanum represents ear. Limbs, when present, are two pairs. Heart is usually three-chambered, but four-chambered in crocodiles. Reptiles are poikilotherms. Snakes and lizards shed their scales as skin cast. Sexes are separate. Fertilisation is internal. They are oviparous and development is direct.

title: Aves (Birds)
content: The characteristic features of Aves (birds) are the presence of feathers and most of them can fly except flightless birds (e.g., Ostrich). They possess beak. The forelimbs are modified into wings. The hind limbs generally have scales and are modified for walking, swimming or clasping the tree branches. Skin is dry without glands except the oil gland at the base of the tail. Endoskeleton is fully ossified (bony) and the long bones are hollow with air cavities (pneumatic). The digestive tract of birds has additional chambers, the crop and gizzard. Heart is completely four-chambered. They are warm-blooded (homoiothermous) animals, i.e., they are able to maintain a constant body temperature. Respiration is by lungs. Air sacs connected to lungs supplement respiration. Sexes are separate. Fertilisation is internal. They are oviparous and development is direct.

title: Homoiothermous (warm-blooded)
content: They are warm-blooded (homoiothermous) animals, i.e., they are able to maintain a constant body temperature.

title: Mammalia
content: The most unique mammalian characteristic is the presence of milk producing glands (mammary glands) by which the young ones are nourished. They have two pairs of limbs, adapted for walking, running, climbing, burrowing, swimming or flying. The skin of mammals is unique in possessing hair. External ears or pinnae are present. Different types of teeth are present in the jaw. Heart is four-chambered. They are homoiothermous. Respiration is by lungs. Sexes are separate and fertilisation is internal. They are viviparous with few exceptions and development is direct.

title: Tap root system
content: In majority of the dicotyledonous plants, the direct elongation of the radicle leads to the formation of primary root which grows inside the soil. It bears lateral roots of several orders that are referred to as secondary, tertiary, etc. roots. The primary roots and its branches constitute the tap root system, as seen in the mustard plant.

title: Fibrous root system
content: In monocotyledonous plants, the primary root is short lived and is replaced by a large number of roots. These roots originate from the base of the stem and constitute the fibrous root system, as seen in the wheat plant.

title: Adventitious roots
content: In some plants, like grass, Monstera and the banyan tree, roots arise from parts of the plant other than the radicle and are called adventitious roots.

title: Root cap
content: The root is covered at the apex by a thimble-like structure called the root cap. It protects the tender apex of the root as it makes its way through the soil.

title: Region of meristematic activity
content: A few millimetres above the root cap is the region of meristematic activity. The cells of this region are very small, thin-walled and with dense protoplasm. They divide repeatedly.

title: Region of elongation
content: The cells proximal to this region undergo rapid elongation and enlargement and are responsible for the growth of the root in length. This region is called the region of elongation.

title: Region of maturation
content: The cells of the elongation zone gradually differentiate and mature. Hence, this zone, proximal to region of elongation, is called the region of maturation.

title: Root hairs
content: From this region some of the epidermal cells form very fine and delicate, thread-like structures called root hairs. These root hairs absorb water and minerals from the soil.

title: Stem
content: The stem is the ascending part of the axis bearing branches, leaves, flowers and fruits. It develops from the plumule of the embryo of a germinating seed. The stem bears nodes and internodes.

title: Nodes
content: The region of the stem where leaves are born are called nodes

title: Internodes
content: internodes are the portions between two nodes.

title: Leaf
content: The leaf is a lateral, generally flattened structure borne on the stem. It develops at the node and bears a bud in its axil. The axillary bud later develops into a branch. Leaves originate from shoot apical meristems and are arranged in an acropetal order. They are the most important vegetative organs for photosynthesis.

title: Stipules
content: The leaf is attached to the stem by the leaf base and may bear two lateral small leaf like structures called stipules.

title: Pulvinus
content: In some leguminous plants the leafbase may become swollen, which is called the pulvinus.

title: Lamina or leaf blade
content: The lamina or the leaf blade is the green expanded part of the leaf with veins and veinlets.

title: Midrib
content: There is, usually, a middle prominent vein, which is known as the midrib.

title: Venation
content: The arrangement of veins and the veinlets in the lamina of leaf is termed as venation.

title: Reticulate venation
content: When the veinlets form a network, the venation is termed as reticulate.

title: Parallel venation
content: When the veins run parallel to each other within a lamina, the venation is termed as parallel.

title: Simple leaf
content: A leaf is said to be simple, when its lamina is entire or when incised, the incisions do not touch the midrib.

title: Compound leaf
content: When the incisions of the lamina reach up to the midrib breaking it into a number of leaflets, the leaf is called compound.

title: Pinnately compound leaf
content: In a pinnately compound leaf a number of leaflets are present on a common axis, the rachis, which represents the midrib of the leaf as in neem.

title: Palmately compound leaves
content: In palmately compound leaves, the leaflets are attached at a common point, i.e., at the tip of petiole, as in silk cotton.

title: Phyllotaxy
content: Phyllotaxy is the pattern of arrangement of leaves on the stem or branch.

title: Alternate phyllotaxy
content: In alternate type of phyllotaxy, a single leaf arises at each node in alternate manner, as in china rose, mustard and sun flower plants.

title: Opposite phyllotaxy
content: In opposite type, a pair of leaves arise at each node and lie opposite to each other as in Calotropis and guava plants.

title: Whorled phyllotaxy
content: If more than two leaves arise at a node and form a whorl, it is called whorled, as in Alstonia.

title: Inflorescence
content: The arrangement of flowers on the floral axis is termed as inflorescence.

title: Racemose inflorescence
content: In racemose type of inflorescences the main axis continues to grow, the flowers are borne laterally in an acropetal succession.

title: Cymose inflorescence
content: In cymose type of inflorescence the main axis terminates in a flower, hence is limited in growth. The flowers are borne in a basipetal order.

title: Flower
content: The flower is the reproductive unit in the angiosperms. It is meant for sexual reproduction.

title: Thalamus or receptacle
content: A typical flower has four different kinds of whorls arranged successively on the swollen end of the stalk or pedicel, called thalamus or receptacle.

title: Perianth
content: In some flowers like lily, the calyx and corolla are not distinct and are termed as perianth.

title: Bisexual flower
content: When a flower has both androecium and gynoecium, it is bisexual.

title: Unisexual flower
content: A flower having either only stamens or only carpels is unisexual.

title: Actinomorphic (radial symmetry)
content: When a flower can be divided into two equal radial halves in any radial plane passing through the centre, it is said to be actinomorphic, e.g., mustard, datura, chilli.

title: Zygomorphic (bilateral symmetry)
content: When it can be divided into two similar halves only in one particular vertical plane, it is zygomorphic, e.g., pea, gulmohur, bean, Cassia.

title: Asymmetric (irregular) flower
content: A flower is asymmetric (irregular) if it cannot be divided into two similar halves by any vertical plane passing through the centre, as in canna.

title: Bracts
content: Flowers with bracts-reduced leaf found at the base of the pedicel-are called bracteate and those without bracts, ebracteate.

title: Hypogynous flower
content: In the hypogynous flower the gynoecium occupies the highest position while the other parts are situated below it. The ovary in such flowers is said to be superior, e.g., mustard, china rose and brinjal.

title: Superior ovary
content: The ovary in such flowers is said to be superior, e.g., mustard, china rose and brinjal.

title: Perigynous flower
content: If gynoecium is situated in the centre and other parts of the flower are located on the rim of the thalamus almost at the same level, it is called perigynous.

title: Half inferior ovary
content: The ovary here is said to be half inferior, e.g., plum, rose, peach.

title: Epigynous flowers
content: In epigynous flowers, the margin of thalamus grows upward enclosing the ovary completely and getting fused with it, the other parts of flower arise above the ovary.

title: Inferior ovary
content: Hence, the ovary is said to be inferior as in flowers of guava and cucumber, and the ray florets of sunflower.

title: Calyx
content: The calyx is the outermost whorl of the flower and the members are called sepals. Generally, sepals are green, leaf like and protect the flower in the bud stage.

title: Sepals
content: The calyx is the outermost whorl of the flower and the members are called sepals.

title: Gamosepalous
content: The calyx may be gamosepalous (sepals united) or polysepalous (sepals free).

title: Polysepalous
content: The calyx may be gamosepalous (sepals united) or polysepalous (sepals free).

title: Corolla
content: Corolla is composed of petals. Petals are usually brightly coloured to attract insects for pollination.

title: Petals
content: Corolla is composed of petals.

title: Gamopetalous
content: Like calyx, corolla may also be gamopetalous (petals united) or polypetalous (petals free).

title: Polypetalous
content: Like calyx, corolla may also be gamopetalous (petals united) or polypetalous (petals free).

title: Aestivation
content: The mode of arrangement of sepals or petals in floral bud with respect to the other members of the same whorl is known as aestivation.

title: Valvate aestivation
content: When sepals or petals in a whorl just touch one another at the margin, without overlapping, as in Calotropis, it is said to be valvate.

title: Twisted aestivation
content: If one margin of the appendage overlaps that of the next one and so on as in china rose, lady’s finger and cotton, it is called twisted.

title: Imbricate aestivation
content: If the margins of sepals or petals overlap one another but not in any particular direction as in Cassia and gulmohur, the aestivation is called imbricate.

title: Vexillary or papilionaceous aestivation
content: In pea and bean flowers, there are five petals, the largest (standard) overlaps the two lateral petals (wings) which in turn overlap the two smallest anterior petals (keel); this type of aestivation is known as vexillary or papilionaceous.

title: Androecium
content: Androecium is composed of stamens. Each stamen which represents the male reproductive organ consists of a stalk or a filament and an anther.

title: Stamen
content: Androecium is composed of stamens. Each stamen which represents the male reproductive organ consists of a stalk or a filament and an anther.

title: Filament
content: Each stamen which represents the male reproductive organ consists of a stalk or a filament and an anther.

title: Anther
content: Each stamen which represents the male reproductive organ consists of a stalk or a filament and an anther.

title: Pollen-sacs
content: Each anther is usually bilobed and each lobe has two chambers, the pollen-sacs.

title: Pollen grains
content: The pollen grains are produced in pollen-sacs.

title: Staminode
content: A sterile stamen is called staminode.

title: Epipetalous
content: When stamens are attached to the petals, they are epipetalous as in brinjal

title: Epiphyllous
content: epiphyllous when attached to the perianth as in the flowers of lily.

title: Polyandrous
content: The stamens in a flower may either remain free (polyandrous) or may be united in varying degrees.

title: Monoadelphous
content: The stamens may be united into one bunch or one bundle (monoadelphous) as in china rose

title: Diadelphous
content: or two bundles (diadelphous) as in pea

title: Polyadelphous
content: or into more than two bundles (polyadelphous) as in citrus.

title: Gynoecium
content: Gynoecium is the female reproductive part of the flower and is made up of one or more carpels.

title: Carpel
content: A carpel consists of three parts namely stigma, style and ovary.

title: Stigma
content: A carpel consists of three parts namely stigma, style and ovary. The stigma is usually at the tip of the style and is the receptive surface for pollen grains.

title: Style
content: A carpel consists of three parts namely stigma, style and ovary. Ovary is the enlarged basal part, on which lies the elongated tube, the style. The style connects the ovary to the stigma.

title: Ovary
content: A carpel consists of three parts namely stigma, style and ovary. Ovary is the enlarged basal part, on which lies the elongated tube, the style.

title: Placenta
content: Each ovary bears one or more ovules attached to a flattened, cushion-like placenta.

title: Apocarpous
content: When more than one carpel is present, they may be free (as in lotus and rose) and are called apocarpous.

title: Syncarpous
content: They are termed syncarpous when carpels are fused, as in mustard and tomato.

title: Placentation
content: The arrangement of ovules within the ovary is known as placentation.

title: Marginal placentation
content: In marginal placentation the placenta forms a ridge along the ventral suture of the ovary and the ovules are borne on this ridge forming two rows, as in pea.

title: Axile placentation
content: When the placenta is axial and the ovules are attached to it in a multilocular ovary, the placentaion is said to be axile, as in china rose, tomato and lemon.

title: Parietal placentation
content: In parietal placentation, the ovules develop on the inner wall of the ovary or on peripheral part. Ovary is one-chambered but it becomes two-chambered due to the formation of the false septum, e.g., mustard and Argemone.

title: Free central placentation
content: When the ovules are borne on central axis and septa are absent, as in Dianthus and Primrose the placentation is called free central.

title: Basal placentation
content: In basal placentation, the placenta develops at the base of ovary and a single ovule is attached to it, as in sunflower, marigold.

title: Fruit
content: The fruit is a characteristic feature of the flowering plants. It is a mature or ripened ovary, developed after fertilisation.

title: Parthenocarpic fruit
content: If a fruit is formed without fertilisation of the ovary, it is called a parthenocarpic fruit.

title: Pericarp
content: Generally, the fruit consists of a wall or pericarp and seeds.

title: Epicarp
content: When pericarp is thick and fleshy, it is differentiated into the outer epicarp, the middle mesocarp and the inner endocarp.

title: Mesocarp
content: When pericarp is thick and fleshy, it is differentiated into the outer epicarp, the middle mesocarp and the inner endocarp.

title: Endocarp
content: When pericarp is thick and fleshy, it is differentiated into the outer epicarp, the middle mesocarp and the inner endocarp.

title: Drupe
content: In mango and coconut, the fruit is known as a drupe. They develop from monocarpellary superior ovaries and are one seeded.

title: Seed
content: The ovules after fertilisation, develop into seeds. A seed is made up of a seed coat and an embryo.

title: Embryo (Seed)
content: The embryo is made up of a radicle, an embryonal axis and one (as in wheat, maize) or two cotyledons (as in gram and pea).

title: Seed coat
content: The outermost covering of a seed is the seed coat. The seed coat has two layers, the outer testa and the inner tegmen.

title: Testa
content: The seed coat has two layers, the outer testa and the inner tegmen.

title: Tegmen
content: The seed coat has two layers, the outer testa and the inner tegmen.

title: Hilum
content: The hilum is a scar on the seed coat through which the developing seeds were attached to the fruit.

title: Micropyle (Seed)
content: Above the hilum is a small pore called the micropyle.

title: Cotyledons
content: Within the seed coat is the embryo, consisting of an embryonal axis and two cotyledons. The cotyledons are often fleshy and full of reserve food materials.

title: Radicle (Seed)
content: At the two ends of the embryonal axis are present the radicle and the plumule.

title: Plumule (Seed)
content: At the two ends of the embryonal axis are present the radicle and the plumule.

title: Endospermic seeds
content: In some seeds such as castor the endosperm formed as a result of double fertilisation, is a food storing tissue and called endospermic seeds.

title: Non-endospermous seeds
content: In plants such as bean, gram and pea, the endosperm is not present in mature seeds and such seeds are called non-endospermous.

title: Non-endospermic (monocotyledonous seeds)
content: Generally, monocotyledonous seeds are endospermic but some as in orchids are non-endospermic.

title: Aleurone layer
content: The outer covering of endosperm separates the embryo by a proteinous layer called aleurone layer.

title: Scutellum
content: It consists of one large and shield shaped cotyledon known as scutellum

title: Coleoptile
content: The plumule and radicle are enclosed in sheaths which are called coleoptile and coleorhiza respectively.

title: Coleorhiza
content: The plumule and radicle are enclosed in sheaths which are called coleoptile and coleorhiza respectively.

chapter: Semi-Technical Description of a Typical Flowering Plant
title: Floral formula
content: The floral formula is represented by some symbols. In the floral formula, Br stands for bracteate K stands for calyx , C for corolla, P for perianth, A for androecium and G for Gynoecium, G for superior ovary and G for inferior ovary, for male, for female, for bisexual plants, for actinomorphic and for zygomorphic nature of flower. Fusion is indicated by enclosing the figure within bracket and adhesion by a line drawn above the symbols of the floral parts.

chapter: Semi-Technical Description of a Typical Flowering Plant
title: Floral diagram
content: A floral diagram provides information about the number of parts of a flower, their arrangement and the relation they have with one another. The position of the mother axis with respect to the flower is represented by a dot on the top of the floral diagram. Calyx, corolla, androecium and gynoecium are drawn in successive whorls, calyx being the outermost and the gynoecium being in the centre. Floral formula also shows cohesion and adhesion within parts of whorls and between whorls.

title: Solanaceae ('potato family')
content: It is a large family, commonly called as the 'potato family'. It is widely distributed in tropics, subtropics and even temperate zones.

title: Anatomy (Plants)
content: Study of internal structure of plants is called anatomy.

title: Epidermal tissue system
content: The epidermal tissue system forms the outer-most covering of the whole plant body and comprises epidermal cells, stomata and the epidermal appendages – the trichomes and hairs.

title: Epidermis (Plant)
content: The epidermis is the outermost layer of the primary plant body. It is made up of elongated, compactly arranged cells, which form a continuous layer. Epidermis is usually single-layered. Epidermal cells are parenchymatous with a small amount of cytoplasm lining the cell wall and a large vacuole.

title: Cuticle (Plant)
content: The outside of the epidermis is often covered with a waxy thick layer called the cuticle which prevents the loss of water. Cuticle is absent in roots.

title: Stomata
content: Stomata are structures present in the epidermis of leaves. Stomata regulate the process of transpiration and gaseous exchange.

title: Guard cells
content: Each stoma is composed of two bean-shaped cells known as guard cells which enclose stomatal pore. In grasses, the guard cells are dumb-bell shaped.

title: Subsidiary cells
content: Sometimes, a few epidermal cells, in the vicinity of the guard cells become specialised in their shape and size and are known as subsidiary cells.

title: Stomatal apparatus
content: The stomatal aperture, guard cells and the surrounding subsidiary cells are together called stomatal apparatus.

title: Root hairs
content: The root hairs are unicellular elongations of the epidermal cells and help absorb water and minerals from the soil.

title: Trichomes
content: On the stem the epidermal hairs are called trichomes. The trichomes in the shoot system are usually multicellular. They may be branched or unbranched and soft or stiff. They may even be secretory. The trichomes help in preventing water loss due to transpiration.

title: Ground tissue
content: All tissues except epidermis and vascular bundles constitute the ground tissue. It consists of simple tissues such as parenchyma, collenchyma and sclerenchyma.

title: Mesophyll
content: In leaves, the ground tissue consists of thin-walled chloroplast containing cells and is called mesophyll.

title: Vascular bundles
content: The xylem and phloem together constitute vascular bundles.

title: Open vascular bundles
content: In dicotyledonous stems, cambium is present between phloem and xylem. Such vascular bundles because of the presence of cambium possess the ability to form secondary xylem and phloem tissues, and hence are called open vascular bundles.

title: Closed vascular bundles
content: In the monocotyledons, the vascular bundles have no cambium present in them. Hence, since they do not form secondary tissues they are referred to as closed.

title: Radial vascular bundles
content: When xylem and phloem within a vascular bundle are arranged in an alternate manner along the different radii, the arrangement is called radial such as in roots.

title: Conjoint vascular bundles
content: In conjoint type of vascular bundles, the xylem and phloem are jointly situated along the same radius of vascular bundles. Such vascular bundles are common in stems and leaves. The conjoint vascular bundles usually have the phloem located only on the outer side of xylem.

title: Epiblema
content: The outermost layer is epiblema. Many of the cells of epiblema protrude in the form of unicellular root hairs.

title: Cortex (Root)
content: The cortex consists of several layers of thin-walled parenchyma cells with intercellular spaces.

title: Endodermis (Root)
content: The innermost layer of the cortex is called endodermis. It comprises a single layer of barrel-shaped cells without any intercellular spaces. The tangential as well as radial walls of the endodermal cells have a deposition of water-impermeable, waxy material suberin in the form of casparian strips.

title: Casparian strips
content: The tangential as well as radial walls of the endodermal cells have a deposition of water-impermeable, waxy material suberin in the form of casparian strips.

title: Pericycle (Root)
content: Next to endodermis lies a few layers of thick-walled parenchyomatous cells referred to as pericycle. Initiation of lateral roots and vascular cambium during the secondary growth takes place in these cells.

title: Conjunctive tissue
content: The parenchymatous cells which lie between the xylem and the phloem are called conjuctive tissue.

title: Stele
content: All tissues on the innerside of the endodermis such as pericycle, vascular bundles and pith constitute the stele.

title: Hypodermis (Stem)
content: The outer hypodermis, consists of a few layers of collenchymatous cells just below the epidermis, which provide mechanical strength to the young stem.

title: Starch sheath
content: The innermost layer of the cortex is called the endodermis. The cells of the endodermis are rich in starch grains and the layer is also referred to as the starch sheath.

title: Medullary rays
content: In between the vascular bundles there are a few layers of radially placed parenchymatous cells, which constitute medullary rays.

title: Adaxial epidermis
content: The epidermis which covers both the upper surface (adaxial epidermis) and lower surface (abaxial epidermis) of the leaf has a conspicuous cuticle.

title: Abaxial epidermis
content: The epidermis which covers both the upper surface (adaxial epidermis) and lower surface (abaxial epidermis) of the leaf has a conspicuous cuticle.

title: Mesophyll (Leaf)
content: The tissue between the upper and the lower epidermis is called the mesophyll. Mesophyll, which possesses chloroplasts and carry out photosynthesis, is made up of parenchyma. It has two types of cells – the palisade parenchyma and the spongy parenchyma.

title: Palisade parenchyma
content: The adaxially placed palisade parenchyma is made up of elongated cells, which are arranged vertically and parallel to each other.

title: Spongy parenchyma
content: The oval or round and loosely arranged spongy parenchyma is situated below the palisade cells and extends to the lower epidermis. There are numerous large spaces and air cavities between these cells.

title: Bulliform cells
content: In grasses, certain adaxial epidermal cells along the veins modify themselves into large, empty, colourless cells. These are called bulliform cells.

title: Tissue (Animals)
content: In multicellular animals, a group of similar cells alongwith intercellular substances perform a specific function. Such an organisation is called tissue.

title: Organ
content: These tissues are organised in specific proportion and pattern to form an organ like stomach, lung, heart and kidney.

title: Organ system
content: When two or more organs perform a common function by their physical and/or chemical interaction, they together form organ system, e.g., digestive system, respiratory system, etc.

title: Morphology (Animals)
content: Morphology refers to study of form or externally visible features. In case of animals this refers to the external appearance of the organs or parts of the body.

title: Anatomy (Animals)
content: The word anatomy conventionally is used for the study of morphology of internal organs in the animals.

title: Cold blooded or poikilotherms
content: They do not have constant body temperature i.e., their body temperature varies with the temperature of the environment. Such animals are called cold blooded or poikilotherms.

title: Mimicry (Frog)
content: They have the ability to change the colour to hide them from their enemies (camouflage). This protective coloration is called mimicry.

title: Summer sleep (aestivation)
content: During this period they take shelter in deep burrows to protect them from extreme heat and cold. This is known as summer sleep (aestivation) and winter sleep (hibernation) respectively.

title: Winter sleep (hibernation)
content: During this period they take shelter in deep burrows to protect them from extreme heat and cold. This is known as summer sleep (aestivation) and winter sleep (hibernation) respectively.

title: Nictitating membrane
content: Eyes are bulged and covered by a nictitating membrane that protects them while in water.

title: Tympanum (ear)
content: On either side of eyes a membranous tympanum (ear) receives sound signals.

title: Sexual dimorphism (Frog)
content: Frogs exhibit sexual dimorphism. Male frogs can be distinguished by the presence of sound producing vocal sacs and also a copulatory pad on the first digit of the fore limbs which are absent in female frogs.

title: Alimentary canal (Frog)
content: The digestive system consists of alimentary canal and digestive glands. The alimentary canal is short because frogs are carnivores and hence the length of intestine is reduced. The mouth opens into the buccal cavity that leads to the oesophagus through pharynx. Oesophagus is a short tube that opens into the stomach which in turn continues as the intestine, rectum and finally opens outside by the cloaca.

title: Cloaca (Frog)
content: Oesophagus is a short tube that opens into the stomach which in turn continues as the intestine, rectum and finally opens outside by the cloaca.

title: Chyme (Frog)
content: Partially digested food called chyme is passed from stomach to the first part of the small intestine, the duodenum.

title: Villi and microvilli (Frog)
content: Digested food is absorbed by the numerous finger-like folds in the inner wall of intestine called villi and microvilli.

title: Cutaneous respiration
content: In water, skin acts as aquatic respiratory organ (cutaneous respiration). Dissolved oxygen in the water is exchanged through the skin by diffusion.

title: Pulmonary respiration
content: On land, the buccal cavity, skin and lungs act as the respiratory organs. The respiration by lungs is called pulmonary respiration.

title: Lymphatic system (Frog)
content: Frogs have a lymphatic system also. The lymphatic system consists of lymph, lymph channels and lymph nodes.

title: Pericardium (Frog)
content: Heart is a muscular structure situated in the upper part of the body cavity. It has three chambers, two atria and one ventricle and is covered by a membrane called pericardium.

title: Sinus venosus (Frog)
content: A triangular structure called sinus venosus joins the right atrium. It receives blood through the major veins called vena cava.

title: Conus arteriosus (Frog)
content: The ventricle opens into a sac-like conus arteriosus on the ventral side of the heart.

title: Hepatic portal system (Frog)
content: Special venous connection between liver and intestine as well as the kidney and lower parts of the body are present in frogs. The former is called hepatic portal system

title: Renal portal system (Frog)
content: Special venous connection between liver and intestine as well as the kidney and lower parts of the body are present in frogs. The former is called hepatic portal system and the latter is called renal portal system.

title: Uriniferous tubules or nephrons (Frog)
content: Each kidney is composed of several structural and functional units called uriniferous tubules or nephrons.

title: Ureotelic animal (Frog)
content: The frog excretes urea and thus is a ureotelic animal.

title: Mesorchium
content: Male reproductive organs consist of a pair of yellowish ovoid testes, which are found adhered to the upper part of kidneys by a double fold of peritoneum called mesorchium.

title: Vasa efferentia (Frog)
content: Vasa efferentia are 10-12 in number that arise from testes. They enter the kidneys on their side and open into Bidder’s canal.

title: Bidder’s canal
content: Vasa efferentia are 10-12 in number that arise from testes. They enter the kidneys on their side and open into Bidder’s canal.

title: Tadpole
content: Development involves a larval stage called tadpole. Tadpole undergoes metamorphosis to form the adult.

title: Cell
content: Cell is the fundamental structural and functional unit of all living organisms.

title: Unicellular organisms
content: Some are composed of a single cell and are called unicellular organisms.

title: Multicellular organisms
content: Others, like us, composed of many cells, are called multicellular organisms.

title: Cell Theory
content: All living organisms are composed of cells and products of cells. All cells arise from pre-existing cells.

title: Nucleus (Cell)
content: Inside each cell is a dense membrane bound structure called nucleus. This nucleus contains the chromosomes which in turn contain the genetic material, DNA.

title: Eukaryotic cells
content: Cells that have membrane bound nuclei are called eukaryotic.

title: Prokaryotic cells
content: Cells that lack a membrane bound nucleus are prokaryotic.

title: Cytoplasm
content: In both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, a semi-fluid matrix called cytoplasm occupies the volume of the cell. The cytoplasm is the main arena of cellular activities in both the plant and animal cells. Various chemical reactions occur in it to keep the cell in the ‘living state’.

title: Organelles
content: Besides the nucleus, the eukaryotic cells have other membrane bound distinct structures called organelles like the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), the golgi complex, lysosomes, mitochondria, microbodies and vacuoles. The prokaryotic cells lack such membrane bound organelles.

title: Ribosomes
content: Ribosomes are non-membrane bound organelles found in all cells - both eukaryotic as well as prokaryotic.

title: Centrosome
content: Animal cells contain another non-membrane bound organelle called centrosome which helps in cell division.

title: Plasmids
content: In addition to the genomic DNA (the single chromosome/circular DNA), many bacteria have small circular DNA outside the genomic DNA. These smaller DNA are called plasmids.

title: Mesosome
content: A specialised differentiated form of cell membrane called mesosome is the characteristic of prokaryotes. They are essentially infoldings of cell membrane.

title: Cell envelope
content: Most prokaryotic cells, particularly the bacterial cells, have a chemically complex cell envelope. The cell envelope consists of a tightly bound three layered structure i.e., the outermost glycocalyx followed by the cell wall and then the plasma membrane.

title: Glycocalyx
content: The outermost glycocalyx followed by the cell wall and then the plasma membrane.

title: Slime layer
content: Glycocalyx differs in composition and thickness among different bacteria. It could be a loose sheath called the slime layer in some, while in others it may be thick and tough, called the capsule.

title: Capsule (Glycocalyx)
content: Glycocalyx differs in composition and thickness among different bacteria. It could be a loose sheath called the slime layer in some, while in others it may be thick and tough, called the capsule.

title: Chromatophores
content: In some prokaryotes like cyanobacteria, there are other membranous extensions into the cytoplasm called chromatophores which contain pigments.

title: Flagella (Bacteria)
content: If motile, they have thin filamentous extensions from their cell wall called flagella.

title: Pili
content: Besides flagella, Pili and Fimbriae are also surface structures of the bacteria but do not play a role in motility. The pili are elongated tubular structures made of a special protein.

title: Fimbriae
content: Besides flagella, Pili and Fimbriae are also surface structures of the bacteria but do not play a role in motility. The pili are elongated tubular structures made of a special protein. The fimbriae are small bristle like fibres sprouting out of the cell.

title: Polyribosomes or polysome
content: Several ribosomes may attach to a single mRNA and form a chain called polyribosomes or polysome.

title: Inclusion bodies
content: Reserve material in prokaryotic cells are stored in the cytoplasm in the form of inclusion bodies. These are not bound by any membrane system and lie free in the cytoplasm, e.g., phosphate granules, cyanophycean granules and glycogen granules. Gas vacuoles are found in blue green and purple and green photosynthetic bacteria.

title: Fluid mosaic model
content: An improved model of the structure of cell membrane was proposed by Singer and Nicolson (1972) widely accepted as fluid mosaic model.

title: Passive transport
content: Many molecules can move briefly across the membrane without any requirement of energy and this is called the passive transport.

title: Osmosis
content: Movement of water by diffusion is called osmosis.

title: Active transport
content: A few ions or molecules are transported across the membrane against their concentration gradient, i.e., from lower to the higher concentration. Such a transport is an energy dependent process, in which ATP is utilised and is called active transport, e.g., Na+/K+ Pump.

title: Cell wall (Fungi and Plants)
content: A non-living rigid structure called the cell wall forms an outer covering for the plasma membrane of fungi and plants. Cell wall not only gives shape to the cell and protects the cell from mechanical damage and infection, it also helps in cell-to-cell interaction and provides barrier to undesirable macromolecules.

title: Primary wall
content: The cell wall of a young plant cell, the primary wall is capable of growth, which gradually diminishes as the cell matures and the secondary wall is formed on the inner (towards membrane) side of the cell.

title: Secondary wall
content: The cell wall of a young plant cell, the primary wall is capable of growth, which gradually diminishes as the cell matures and the secondary wall is formed on the inner (towards membrane) side of the cell.

title: Middle lamella
content: The middle lamella is a layer mainly of calcium pectate which holds or glues the different neighbouring cells together.

title: Plasmodesmata
content: The cell wall and middle lamellae may be traversed by plasmodesmata which connect the cytoplasm of neighbouring cells.

title: Endomembrane system
content: While each of the membranous organelles is distinct in terms of its structure and function, many of these are considered together as an endomembrane system because their functions are coordinated. The endomembrane system include endoplasmic reticulum (ER), golgi complex, lysosomes and vacuoles.

title: Endoplasmic reticulum (ER)
content: Electron microscopic studies of eukaryotic cells reveal the presence of a network or reticulum of tiny tubular structures scattered in the cytoplasm that is called the endoplasmic reticulum (ER).

title: Rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER)
content: The ER often shows ribosomes attached to their outer surface. The endoplasmic reticulun bearing ribosomes on their surface is called rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER).

title: Smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER)
content: In the absence of ribosomes they appear smooth and are called smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER).

title: Golgi apparatus or Golgi bodies
content: Camillo Golgi (1898) first observed densely stained reticular structures near the nucleus. These were later named Golgi bodies after him. They consist of many flat, disc-shaped sacs or cisternae of 0.5µm to 1.0µm diameter.

title: Cisternae
content: They consist of many flat, disc-shaped sacs or cisternae of 0.5µm to 1.0µm diameter. These are stacked parallel to each other.

title: Lysosomes
content: These are membrane bound vesicular structures formed by the process of packaging in the golgi apparatus. The isolated lysosomal vesicles have been found to be very rich in almost all types of hydrolytic enzymes (hydrolases – lipases, proteases, carbohydrases) optimally active at the acidic pH. These enzymes are capable of digesting carbohydrates, proteins, lipids and nucleic acids.

title: Vacuole (Cell)
content: The vacuole is the membrane-bound space found in the cytoplasm. It contains water, sap, excretory product and other materials not useful for the cell.

title: Tonoplast
content: The vacuole is bound by a single membrane called tonoplast.

title: Contractile vacuole
content: In Amoeba, the contractile vacuole is important for osmoregulation and excretion.

title: Food vacuoles
content: In many cells, as in protists, food vacuoles are formed by engulfing the food particles.

title: Mitochondria
content: Each mitochondrion is a double membrane-bound structure with the outer membrane and the inner membrane dividing its lumen distinctly into two aqueous compartments, i.e., the outer compartment and the inner compartment. The inner compartment is filled with a dense homogeneous substance called the matrix. The outer membrane forms the continuous limiting boundary of the organelle. The inner membrane forms a number of infoldings called the cristae (sing.: crista) towards the matrix.

title: Matrix (Mitochondria)
content: The inner compartment is filled with a dense homogeneous substance called the matrix.

title: Cristae
content: The inner membrane forms a number of infoldings called the cristae (sing.: crista) towards the matrix.

title: Plastids
content: Plastids are found in all plant cells and in euglenoides. These are easily observed under the microscope as they are large. They bear some specific pigments, thus imparting specific colours to the plants. Based on the type of pigments plastids can be classified into chloroplasts, chromoplasts and leucoplasts.

title: Chloroplasts
content: The chloroplasts contain chlorophyll and carotenoid pigments which are responsible for trapping light energy essential for photosynthesis.

title: Chromoplasts
content: In the chromoplasts, fat soluble carotenoid pigments like carotene, xanthophylls and others are present. This gives the part of the plant a yellow, orange or red colour.

title: Leucoplasts
content: The leucoplasts are the colourless plastids of varied shapes and sizes with stored nutrients: Amyloplasts store carbohydrates (starch), e.g., potato; elaioplasts store oils and fats whereas the aleuroplasts store proteins.

title: Amyloplasts
content: Amyloplasts store carbohydrates (starch), e.g., potato.

title: Elaioplasts
content: Elaioplasts store oils and fats.

title: Aleuroplasts
content: Aleuroplasts store proteins.

title: Stroma (Chloroplast)
content: The space limited by the inner membrane of the chloroplast is called the stroma.

title: Thylakoids
content: A number of organised flattened membranous sacs called the thylakoids, are present in the stroma. Thylakoids are arranged in stacks like the piles of coins called grana (singular: granum) or the intergranal thylakoids.

title: Grana
content: Thylakoids are arranged in stacks like the piles of coins called grana (singular: granum) or the intergranal thylakoids.

title: Stroma lamellae
content: In addition, there are flat membranous tubules called the stroma lamellae connecting the thylakoids of the different grana.

title: Cytoskeleton
content: An elaborate network of filamentous proteinaceous structures consisting of microtubules, microfilaments and intermediate filaments present in the cytoplasm is collectively referred to as the cytoskeleton.

title: Cilia
content: Cilia (sing.: cilium) and flagella (sing.: flagellum) are hair-like outgrowths of the cell membrane. Cilia are small structures which work like oars, causing the movement of either the cell or the surrounding fluid.

title: Flagella (Eukaryotic)
content: Cilia (sing.: cilium) and flagella (sing.: flagellum) are hair-like outgrowths of the cell membrane. Flagella are comparatively longer and responsible for cell movement.

title: Axoneme
content: Their core called the axoneme, possesses a number of microtubules running parallel to the long axis. The axoneme usually has nine doublets of radially arranged peripheral microtubules, and a pair of centrally located microtubules. Such an arrangement of axonemal microtubules is referred to as the 9+2 array.

title: Centrosome
content: Centrosome is an organelle usually containing two cylindrical structures called centrioles. They are surrounded by amorphous pericentriolar materials.

title: Centrioles
content: Centrosome is an organelle usually containing two cylindrical structures called centrioles.

title: Chromatin
content: Later the material of the nucleus stained by the basic dyes was given the name chromatin by Flemming. The interphase nucleus (nucleus of a cell when it is not dividing) has highly extended and elaborate nucleoprotein fibres called chromatin, nuclear matrix and one or more spherical bodies called nucleoli (sing.: nucleolus).

title: Nuclear envelope
content: Electron microscopy has revealed that the nuclear envelope, which consists of two parallel membranes with a space between (10 to 50 nm) called the perinuclear space, forms a barrier between the materials present inside the nucleus and that of the cytoplasm.

title: Perinuclear space
content: Electron microscopy has revealed that the nuclear envelope, which consists of two parallel membranes with a space between (10 to 50 nm) called the perinuclear space, forms a barrier between the materials present inside the nucleus and that of the cytoplasm.

title: Nuclear pores
content: At a number of places the nuclear envelope is interrupted by minute pores, which are formed by the fusion of its two membranes. These nuclear pores are the passages through which movement of RNA and protein molecules takes place in both directions between the nucleus and the cytoplasm.

title: Nucleoplasm
