content: The nuclear matrix or the nucleoplasm contains nucleolus and chromatin.

title: Nucleolus
content: The interphase nucleus (nucleus of a cell when it is not dividing) has highly extended and elaborate nucleoprotein fibres called chromatin, nuclear matrix and one or more spherical bodies called nucleoli (sing.: nucleolus). The nucleoli are spherical structures present in the nucleoplasm. The content of nucleolus is continuous with the rest of the nucleoplasm as it is not a membrane bound structure. It is a site for active ribosomal RNA synthesis.

title: Chromosomes
content: But during different stages of cell division, cells show structured chromosomes in place of the nucleus. Chromatin contains DNA and some basic proteins called histones, some non-histone proteins and also RNA.

title: Centromere
content: Every chromosome (visible only in dividing cells) essentially has a primary constriction or the centromere on the sides of which disc shaped structures called kinetochores are present.

title: Kinetochores
content: Every chromosome (visible only in dividing cells) essentially has a primary constriction or the centromere on the sides of which disc shaped structures called kinetochores are present.

title: Metacentric chromosome
content: The metacentric chromosome has middle centromere forming two equal arms of the chromosome.

title: Sub-metacentric chromosome
content: The sub-metacentric chromosome has centromere slightly away from the middle of the chromosome resulting into one shorter arm and one longer arm.

title: Acrocentric chromosome
content: In case of acrocentric chromosome the centromere is situated close to its end forming one extremely short and one very long arm.

title: Telocentric chromosome
content: The telocentric chromosome has a terminal centromere.

title: Satellite (Chromosome)
content: Sometimes a few chromosomes have non-staining secondary constrictions at a constant location. This gives the appearance of a small fragment called the satellite.

title: Microbodies
content: Many membrane bound minute vesicles called microbodies that contain various enzymes, are present in both plant and animal cells.

title: Acid-soluble pool (filtrate)
content: We can take any living tissue (a vegetable or a piece of liver, etc.) and grind it in trichloroacetic acid (Cl3CCOOH) using a mortar and a pestle. We obtain a thick slurry. If we were to strain this through a cheesecloth or cotton we would obtain two fractions. One is called the filtrate or more technically, the acid-soluble pool, and the second, the retentate or the acid-insoluble fraction.

title: Acid-insoluble fraction (retentate)
content: We can take any living tissue (a vegetable or a piece of liver, etc.) and grind it in trichloroacetic acid (Cl3CCOOH) using a mortar and a pestle. We obtain a thick slurry. If we were to strain this through a cheesecloth or cotton we would obtain two fractions. One is called the filtrate or more technically, the acid-soluble pool, and the second, the retentate or the acid-insoluble fraction.

title: Biomolecules
content: All the carbon compounds that we get from living tissues can be called ‘biomolecules’. However, living organisms have also got inorganic elements and compounds in them.

title: Wet weight
content: One weighs a small amount of a living tissue (say a leaf or liver and this is called wet weight) and dry it.

title: Dry weight
content: All the water, evaporates. The remaining material gives dry weight.

title: Ash
content: Now if the tissue is fully burnt, all the carbon compounds are oxidised to gaseous form (CO2, water vapour) and are removed. What is remaining is called ‘ash’. This ash contains inorganic elements (like calcium, magnesium etc).

title: Amino acids
content: Amino acids are organic compounds containing an amino group and an acidic group as substituents on the same carbon i.e., the α-carbon. Hence, they are called α-amino acids.

title: Saturated fatty acids
content: Fatty acids could be saturated (without double bond) or unsaturated (with one or more C=C double bonds).

title: Unsaturated fatty acids
content: Fatty acids could be saturated (without double bond) or unsaturated (with one or more C=C double bonds).

title: Glycerol
content: Another simple lipid is glycerol which is trihydroxy propane.

title: Monoglycerides, diglycerides and triglycerides
content: Many lipids have both glycerol and fatty acids. Here the fatty acids are found esterified with glycerol. They can be then monoglycerides, diglycerides and triglycerides.

title: Fats and oils
content: These are also called fats and oils based on melting point. Oils have lower melting point (e.g., gingelly oil) and hence remain as oil in winters.

title: Phospholipids
content: Some lipids have phosphorous and a phosphorylated organic compound in them. These are phospholipids. They are found in cell membrane. Lecithin is one example.

title: Nitrogen bases
content: Living organisms have a number of carbon compounds in which heterocyclic rings can be found. Some of these are nitrogen bases - adenine, guanine, cytosine, uracil, and thymine.

title: Nucleosides
content: When found attached to a sugar, they are called nucleosides.

title: Nucleotides
content: If a phosphate group is also found esterified to the sugar they are called nucleotides.

title: Nucleic acids
content: Nucleic acids like DNA and RNA consist of nucleotides only. DNA and RNA function as genetic material.

title: Metabolites
content: If one were to make a list of biomolecules, such a list would have thousands of organic compounds including amino acids, sugars, etc. For reasons that are given in section 9.10, we can call these biomolecules as ‘metabolites’.

title: Primary metabolites
content: In animal tissues, one notices the presence of all such categories of compounds shown in Figure 9.1. These are primary metabolites.

title: Secondary metabolites
content: However, when one analyses plant, fungal and microbial cells, one would see thousands of compounds other than these primary metabolites, e.g. alkaloids, flavonoids, rubber, essential oils, antibiotics, coloured pigments, scents, gums, spices. These are called secondary metabolites.

title: Micromolecules or biomolecules
content: For this very reason, biomolecules, i.e., chemical compounds found in living organisms are of two types. One, those which have molecular weights less than one thousand dalton and are usually referred to as micromolecules or simply biomolecules.

title: Macromolecules or biomacromolecules
content: For this very reason, biomolecules, i.e., chemical compounds found in living organisms are of two types. While those which are found in the acid insoluble fraction are called macromolecules or biomacromolecules.

title: Proteins
content: Proteins are polypeptides. They are linear chains of amino acids linked by peptide bonds. Each protein is a polymer of amino acids. As there are 20 types of amino acids (e.g., alanine, cysteine, proline, tryptophan, lysine, etc.), a protein is a heteropolymer and not a homopolymer.

title: Heteropolymer (Proteins)
content: As there are 20 types of amino acids (e.g., alanine, cysteine, proline, tryptophan, lysine, etc.), a protein is a heteropolymer and not a homopolymer.

title: Homopolymer
content: A homopolymer has only one type of monomer repeating ‘n’ number of times.

title: Essential amino acids
content: This information about the amino acid content is important as later in your nutrition lessons, you will learn that certain amino acids are essential for our health and they have to be supplied through our diet. Hence, dietary proteins are the source of essential amino acids. Therefore, amino acids can be essential or non-essential.

title: Non-essential amino acids
content: The latter are those which our body can make, while we get essential amino acids through our diet/food.

title: Polysaccharides
content: Polysaccharides are long chains of sugars. They are threads (literally a cotton thread) containing different monosaccharides as building blocks.

title: Cellulose (Polysaccharide)
content: For example, cellulose is a polymeric polysaccharide consisting of only one type of monosaccharide i.e., glucose. Cellulose is a homopolymer.

title: Starch
content: Starch is a variant of this but present as a store house of energy in plant tissues.

title: Glycogen
content: Animals have another variant called glycogen.

title: Inulin
content: Inulin is a polymer of fructose.

title: Chitin
content: Exoskeletons of arthropods, for example, have a complex polysaccharide called chitin.

title: Polynucleotides
content: The other type of macromolecule that one would find in the acid insoluble fraction of any living tissue is the nucleic acid. These are polynucleotides.

title: Nucleotide (Building block)
content: For nucleic acids, the building block is a nucleotide. A nucleotide has three chemically distinct components. One is a heterocyclic compound, the second is a monosaccharide and the third a phosphoric acid or phosphate.

title: Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)
content: A nucleic acid containing deoxyribose is called deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA).

title: Ribonucleic acid (RNA)
content: While that which contains ribose is called ribonucleic acid (RNA).

title: Primary structure (Protein)
content: The sequence of amino acids i.e., the positional information in a protein – which is the first amino acid, which is second, and so on – is called the primary structure of a protein.

title: N-terminal amino acid
content: A protein is imagined as a line, the left end represented by the first amino acid and the right end represented by the last amino acid. The first amino acid is also called as N-terminal amino acid.

title: C-terminal amino acid
content: The last amino acid is called the C-terminal amino acid.

title: Secondary structure (Protein)
content: The thread is folded in the form of a helix (similar to a revolving staircase). Of course, only some portions of the protein thread are arranged in the form of a helix. In proteins, only right handed helices are observed. Other regions of the protein thread are folded into other forms in what is called the secondary structure.

title: Tertiary structure (Protein)
content: In addition, the long protein chain is also folded upon itself like a hollow woolen ball, giving rise to the tertiary structure. This gives us a 3-dimensional view of a protein. Tertiary structure is absolutely necessary for the many biological activities of proteins.

title: Quaternary structure (Protein)
content: Some proteins are an assembly of more than one polypeptide or subunits. The manner in which these individual folded polypeptides or subunits are arranged with respect to each other (e.g. linear string of spheres, spheres arranged one upon each other in the form of a cube or plate etc.) is the architecture of a protein otherwise called the quaternary structure of a protein.

title: Enzymes
content: Almost all enzymes are proteins. There are some nucleic acids that behave like enzymes. These are called ribozymes.

title: Ribozymes
content: There are some nucleic acids that behave like enzymes. These are called ribozymes.

title: Active site (Enzyme)
content: When you look at a tertiary structure upon itself, the chain criss-crosses itself and hence, many crevices or pockets are made. One such pocket is the ‘active site’. An active site of an enzyme is a crevice or pocket into which the substrate fits. Thus enzymes, through their active site, catalyse reactions at a high rate.

title: Chemical reaction
content: However, when bonds are broken and new bonds are formed during transformation, this will be called a chemical reaction.

chapter: How do Enzymes bring about such High Rates of Chemical Conversions?
title: Substrate (Enzyme)
content: The chemical which is converted into a product is called a ‘substrate’.

chapter: How do Enzymes bring about such High Rates of Chemical Conversions?
title: ES complex (Enzyme-substrate complex)
content: There is thus, an obligatory formation of an ‘ES’ complex. E stands for enzyme. This complex formation is a transient phenomenon.

chapter: How do Enzymes bring about such High Rates of Chemical Conversions?
title: Transition state structure
content: During the state where substrate is bound to the enzyme active site, a new structure of the substrate called transition state structure is formed.

chapter: How do Enzymes bring about such High Rates of Chemical Conversions?
title: Activation energy
content: The difference in average energy content of ‘S’ from that of this transition state is called ‘activation energy’.

title: Optimum temperature (Enzyme)
content: Each enzyme shows its highest activity at a particular temperature and pH called the optimum temperature and optimum pH.

title: Optimum pH (Enzyme)
content: Each enzyme shows its highest activity at a particular temperature and pH called the optimum temperature and optimum pH.

title: Inhibition (Enzyme)
content: The activity of an enzyme is also sensitive to the presence of specific chemicals that bind to the enzyme. When the binding of the chemical shuts off enzyme activity, the process is called inhibition and the chemical is called an inhibitor.

title: Inhibitor
content: The activity of an enzyme is also sensitive to the presence of specific chemicals that bind to the enzyme. When the binding of the chemical shuts off enzyme activity, the process is called inhibition and the chemical is called an inhibitor.

title: Competitive inhibitor
content: When the inhibitor closely resembles the substrate in its molecular structure and inhibits the activity of the enzyme, it is known as competitive inhibitor. Due to its close structural similarity with the substrate, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for the substrate-binding site of the enzyme. Consequently, the substrate cannot bind and as a result, the enzyme action declines, e.g., inhibition of succinic dehydrogenase by malonate which closely resembles the substrate succinate in structure.

title: Oxidoreductases/dehydrogenases
content: Enzymes which catalyse oxidoreduction between two substrates S and S’ e.g., S reduced + S’ oxidised  → S oxidised + S’ reduced.

title: Transferases
content: Enzymes catalysing a transfer of a group, G (other than hydrogen) between a pair of substrate S and S’ e.g., S - G + S’  → S + S’ - G.

title: Hydrolases
content: Enzymes catalysing hydrolysis of ester, ether, peptide, glycosidic, C-C, C-halide or P-N bonds.

title: Lyases
content: Enzymes that catalyse removal of groups from substrates by mechanisms other than hydrolysis leaving double bonds.

title: Isomerases
content: Includes all enzymes catalysing inter-conversion of optical, geometric or positional isomers.

title: Ligases
content: Enzymes catalysing the linking together of 2 compounds, e.g., enzymes which catalyse joining of C-O, C-S, C-N, P-O etc. bonds.

title: Co-factors (Enzymes)
content: However, there are a number of cases in which non-protein constituents called co-factors are bound to the the enzyme to make the enzyme catalytically active.

title: Apoenzyme
content: In these instances, the protein portion of the enzymes is called the apoenzyme.

title: Prosthetic groups
content: Prosthetic groups are organic compounds and are distinguished from other cofactors in that they are tightly bound to the apoenzyme.

title: Co-enzymes
content: Co-enzymes are also organic compounds but their association with the apoenzyme is only transient, usually occurring during the course of catalysis. Furthermore, co-enzymes serve as co-factors in a number of different enzyme catalyzed reactions. The essential chemical components of many coenzymes are vitamins, e.g., coenzyme nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) and NADP contain the vitamin niacin.

title: Metal ions (Enzyme cofactor)
content: A number of enzymes require metal ions for their activity which form coordination bonds with side chains at the active site and at the same time form one or more cordination bonds with the substrate, e.g., zinc is a cofactor for the proteolytic enzyme carboxypeptidase.

title: Cell cycle
content: The sequence of events by which a cell duplicates its genome, synthesises the other constituents of the cell and eventually divides into two daughter cells is termed cell cycle.

title: Interphase
content: The cell cycle is divided into two basic phases: Interphase and M Phase (Mitosis phase). The interphase represents the phase between two successive M phases.

title: M Phase (Mitosis phase)
content: The cell cycle is divided into two basic phases: Interphase and M Phase (Mitosis phase). The M Phase represents the phase when the actual cell division or mitosis occurs.

title: Karyokinesis
content: The M Phase starts with the nuclear division, corresponding to the separation of daughter chromosomes (karyokinesis) and usually ends with division of cytoplasm (cytokinesis).

title: Cytokinesis
content: The M Phase starts with the nuclear division, corresponding to the separation of daughter chromosomes (karyokinesis) and usually ends with division of cytoplasm (cytokinesis).

title: G1 phase (Gap 1)
content: The interphase is divided into three further phases: G1 phase (Gap 1), S phase (Synthesis), G2 phase (Gap 2). G1 phase corresponds to the interval between mitosis and initiation of DNA replication. During G1 phase, the cell is metabolically active and continuously grows but does not replicate its DNA.

title: S phase (Synthesis)
content: S or synthesis phase marks the period during which DNA synthesis or replication takes place. During this time the amount of DNA per cell doubles.

title: G2 phase (Gap 2)
content: During the G2 phase, proteins are synthesised in preparation for mitosis while cell growth continues.

title: Quiescent stage (G0)
content: These cells that do not divide further exit G1 phase to enter an inactive stage called quiescent stage (G0) of the cell cycle. Cells in this stage remain metabolically active but no longer proliferate unless called on to do so depending on the requirement of the organism.

title: Equational division (Mitosis)
content: Since the number of chromosomes in the parent and progeny cells is the same, it is also called as equational division.

title: Prophase (Mitosis)
content: Prophase which is the first stage of karyokinesis of mitosis follows the S and G2 phases of interphase. Prophase is marked by the initiation of condensation of chromosomal material. The chromosomal material becomes untangled during the process of chromatin condensation.

title: Mitotic apparatus
content: Each centrosome radiates out microtubules called asters. The two asters together with spindle fibres forms mitotic apparatus.

title: Metaphase (Mitosis)
content: The complete disintegration of the nuclear envelope marks the start of the second phase of mitosis. By this stage, condensation of chromosomes is completed and they can be observed clearly under the microscope. This then, is the stage at which morphology of chromosomes is most easily studied.

title: Kinetochores
content: Small disc-shaped structures at the surface of the centromeres are called kinetochores. These structures serve as the sites of attachment of spindle fibres to the chromosomes that are moved into position at the centre of the cell.

title: Metaphase plate
content: The plane of alignment of the chromosomes at metaphase is referred to as the metaphase plate.

title: Anaphase (Mitosis)
content: At the onset of anaphase, each chromosome arranged at the metaphase plate is split simultaneously and the two daughter chromatids, now referred to as daughter chromosomes of the future daughter nuclei, begin their migration towards the two opposite poles.

title: Telophase (Mitosis)
content: At the beginning of the final stage of karyokinesis, i.e., telophase, the chromosomes that have reached their respective poles decondense and lose their individuality. The individual chromosomes can no longer be seen and each set of chromatin material tends to collect at each of the two poles.

title: Cell-plate
content: In plant cells, wall formation starts in the centre of the cell and grows outward to meet the existing lateral walls. The formation of the new cell wall begins with the formation of a simple precursor, called the cell-plate that represents the middle lamella between the walls of two adjacent cells.

title: Syncytium
content: In some organisms karyokinesis is not followed by cytokinesis as a result of which multinucleate condition arises leading to the formation of syncytium (e.g., liquid endosperm in coconut).

title: Meiosis
content: This specialised kind of cell division that reduces the chromosome number by half results in the production of haploid daughter cells. This kind of division is called meiosis.

title: Meiosis I
content: Meiosis involves two sequential cycles of nuclear and cell division called meiosis I and meiosis II but only a single cycle of DNA replication.

title: Meiosis II
content: Meiosis involves two sequential cycles of nuclear and cell division called meiosis I and meiosis II but only a single cycle of DNA replication.

title: Leptotene
content: Prophase of the first meiotic division is typically longer and more complex when compared to prophase of mitosis. It has been further subdivided into the following five phases based on chromosomal behaviour, i.e., Leptotene, Zygotene, Pachytene, Diplotene and Diakinesis. During leptotene stage the chromosomes become gradually visible under the light microscope. The compaction of chromosomes continues throughout leptotene.

title: Zygotene
content: This is followed by the second stage of prophase I called zygotene. During this stage, chromosomes start pairing together and this process of association is called synapsis.

title: Synapsis
content: During this stage (zygotene), chromosomes start pairing together and this process of association is called synapsis.

title: Homologous chromosomes
content: Such paired chromosomes are called homologous chromosomes.

title: Synaptonemal complex
content: Electron micrographs of this stage (zygotene), indicate that chromosome synapsis is accompanied by the formation of complex structure called synaptonemal complex.

title: Bivalent or tetrad (Meiosis I)
content: The complex formed by a pair of synapsed homologous chromosomes is called a bivalent or a tetrad.

title: Pachytene
content: The first two stages of prophase I are relatively short-lived compared to the next stage that is pachytene. During this stage, the four chromatids of each bivalent chromosomes becomes distinct and clearly appear as tetrads. This stage is characterised by the appearance of recombination nodules, the sites at which crossing over occurs between non-sister chromatids of the homologous chromosomes.

title: Recombination nodules
content: This stage (pachytene) is characterised by the appearance of recombination nodules, the sites at which crossing over occurs between non-sister chromatids of the homologous chromosomes.

title: Crossing over
content: Crossing over is the exchange of genetic material between two homologous chromosomes. Crossing over is also an enzyme-mediated process and the enzyme involved is called recombinase.

title: Recombinase
content: Crossing over is also an enzyme-mediated process and the enzyme involved is called recombinase.

title: Diplotene
content: The beginning of diplotene is recognised by the dissolution of the synaptonemal complex and the tendency of the recombined homologous chromosomes of the bivalents to separate from each other except at the sites of crossovers.

title: Chiasmata
content: These X-shaped structures, are called chiasmata.

title: Diakinesis
content: The final stage of meiotic prophase I is diakinesis. This is marked by terminalisation of chiasmata. During this phase the chromosomes are fully condensed and the meiotic spindle is assembled to prepare the homologous chromosomes for separation. By the end of diakinesis, the nucleolus disappears and the nuclear envelope also breaks down.

title: Metaphase I (Meiosis)
content: The bivalent chromosomes align on the equatorial plate. The microtubules from the opposite poles of the spindle attach to the kinetochore of homologous chromosomes.

title: Anaphase I (Meiosis)
content: The homologous chromosomes separate, while sister chromatids remain associated at their centromeres.

title: Telophase I (Meiosis)
content: The nuclear membrane and nucleolus reappear, cytokinesis follows and this is called as dyad of cells.

title: Interkinesis
content: The stage between the two meiotic divisions is called interkinesis and is generally short lived. There is no replication of DNA during interkinesis.

title: Prophase II (Meiosis)
content: Interkinesis is followed by prophase II, a much simpler prophase than prophase I. Meiosis II is initiated immediately after cytokinesis, usually before the chromosomes have fully elongated. In contrast to meiosis I, meiosis II resembles a normal mitosis. The nuclear membrane disappears by the end of prophase II. The chromosomes again become compact.

title: Metaphase II (Meiosis)
content: At this stage (Metaphase II), the chromosomes align at the equator and the microtubules from opposite poles of the spindle get attached to the kinetochores of sister chromatids.

title: Anaphase II (Meiosis)
content: It begins with the simultaneous splitting of the centromere of each chromosome (which was holding the sister chromatids together), allowing them to move toward opposite poles of the cell by shortening of microtubules attached to kinetochores.

title: Telophase II (Meiosis)
content: Meiosis ends with telophase II, in which the two groups of chromosomes once again get enclosed by a nuclear envelope; cytokinesis follows resulting in the formation of tetrad of cells i.e., four haploid daughter cells.

title: Photosynthesis
content: The green plants make or rather synthesise the food they need through photosynthesis and are therefore called autotrophs. Green plants carry out ‘photosynthesis’, a physico-chemical process by which they use light energy to drive the synthesis of organic compounds.

title: Autotrophs
content: Green plants, in fact, have to make or rather synthesise the food they need and all other organisms depend on them for their needs. The green plants make or rather synthesise the food they need through photosynthesis and are therefore called autotrophs.

title: Heterotrophs
content: You have already learnt that the autotrophic nutrition is found only in plants and all other organisms that depend on the green plants for food are heterotrophs.

title: Light reactions (Photochemical reactions)
content: The membrane system is responsible for trapping the light energy and also for the synthesis of ATP and NADPH. The former set of reactions, since they are directly light driven are called light reactions (photochemical reactions).

title: Dark reactions (Carbon reactions)
content: The latter (enzymatic reactions in stroma) are not directly light driven but are dependent on the products of light reactions (ATP and NADPH). Hence, to distinguish the latter they are called, by convention, as dark reactions (carbon reactions).

chapter: HOW MANY TYPES OF PIGMENTS ARE INVOLVED IN PHOTOSYNTHESIS?
title: Pigments (Photosynthesis)
content: Pigments are substances that have an ability to absorb light, at specific wavelengths.

chapter: HOW MANY TYPES OF PIGMENTS ARE INVOLVED IN PHOTOSYNTHESIS?
title: Accessory pigments
content: Though chlorophyll is the major pigment responsible for trapping light, other thylakoid pigments like chlorophyll b, xanthophylls and carotenoids, which are called accessory pigments, also absorb light and transfer the energy to chlorophyll a. Indeed, they not only enable a wider range of wavelength of incoming light to be utilised for photosyntesis but also protect chlorophyll a from photo-oxidation.

title: Light Harvesting Complexes (LHC)
content: The pigments are organised into two discrete photochemical light harvesting complexes (LHC) within the Photosystem I (PS I) and Photosystem II (PS II). Each photosystem has all the pigments (except one molecule of chlorophyll a) forming a light harvesting system also called antennae.

title: Antennae (Photosynthesis)
content: Each photosystem has all the pigments (except one molecule of chlorophyll a) forming a light harvesting system also called antennae. These pigments help to make photosynthesis more efficient by absorbing different wavelengths of light.

title: Reaction centre (Photosynthesis)
content: The single chlorophyll a molecule forms the reaction centre. The reaction centre is different in both the photosystems. In PS I the reaction centre chlorophyll a has an absorption peak at 700 nm, hence is called P700, while in PS II it has absorption maxima at 680 nm, and is called P680.

title: Photosystem I (PS I)
content: The pigments are organised into two discrete photochemical light harvesting complexes (LHC) within the Photosystem I (PS I) and Photosystem II (PS II). In PS I the reaction centre chlorophyll a has an absorption peak at 700 nm, hence is called P700.

title: Photosystem II (PS II)
content: The pigments are organised into two discrete photochemical light harvesting complexes (LHC) within the Photosystem I (PS I) and Photosystem II (PS II). In PS II it has absorption maxima at 680 nm, and is called P680.

title: Z scheme
content: This whole scheme of transfer of electrons, starting from the PS II, uphill to the acceptor, down the electron transport chain to PS I, excitation of electrons, transfer to another acceptor, and finally down hill to NADP+ reducing it to NADPH + H+ is called the Z scheme, due to its characteristic shape.

title: Phosphorylation (Photosynthesis)
content: The process through which ATP is synthesised by cells (in mitochondria and chloroplasts) is named phosphorylation. Photo-phosphorylation is the synthesis of ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphate in the presence of light.

title: Photo-phosphorylation
content: Photo-phosphorylation is the synthesis of ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphate in the presence of light.

title: Non-cyclic photo-phosphorylation
content: When the two photosystems work in a series, first PS II and then the PS I, a process called non-cyclic photo-phosphorylation occurs. The two photosystems are connected through an electron transport chain, as seen earlier – in the Z scheme. Both ATP and NADPH + H+ are synthesised by this kind of electron flow.

title: Cyclic photo-phosphorylation
content: When only PS I is functional, the electron is circulated within the photosystem and the phosphorylation occurs due to cyclic flow of electrons. The cyclic flow hence, results only in the synthesis of ATP, but not of NADPH + H+.

title: Chemiosmotic hypothesis
content: The chemiosmotic hypothesis has been put forward to explain the mechanism (of ATP synthesis in the chloroplast). Like in respiration, in photosynthesis too, ATP synthesis is linked to development of a proton gradient across a membrane. This time these are the membranes of thylakoid.

title: ATP synthase (Photosynthesis)
content: The ATP synthase enzyme consists of two parts: one called the CF0 is embedded in the thylakoid membrane and forms a transmembrane channel that carries out facilitated diffusion of protons across the membrane. The other portion is called CF1 and protrudes on the outer surface of the thylakoid membrane on the side that faces the stroma.

chapter: WHERE ARE THE ATP AND NADPH USED?
title: Biosynthetic phase (Photosynthesis)
content: The products of light reaction are ATP, NADPH and O2. Of these O2 diffuses out of the chloroplast while ATP and NADPH are used to drive the processes leading to the synthesis of food, more accurately, sugars. This is the biosynthetic phase of photosynthesis.

chapter: WHERE ARE THE ATP AND NADPH USED?
title: Calvin cycle
content: The use of radioactive 14C by him (Melvin Calvin) in algal photosynthesis studies led to the discovery that the first CO2 fixation product was a 3-carbon organic acid. He also contributed to working out the complete biosynthetic pathway; hence it was called Calvin cycle after him.

chapter: WHERE ARE THE ATP AND NADPH USED?
title: PGA (3-phosphoglyceric acid)
content: The first product identified was 3-phosphoglyceric acid or in short PGA.

chapter: WHERE ARE THE ATP AND NADPH USED?
title: OAA (Oxaloacetic acid)
content: Experiments conducted over a wide range of plants led to the discovery of another group of plants, where the first stable product of CO2 fixation was again an organic acid, but one which had 4 carbon atoms in it. This acid was identified to be oxaloacetic acid or OAA.

chapter: WHERE ARE THE ATP AND NADPH USED?
title: C3 pathway
content: Since then CO2 assimilation during photosynthesis was said to be of two main types: those plants in which the first product of CO2 fixation is a C3 acid (PGA), i.e., the C3 pathway, and those in which the first product was a C4 acid (OAA), i.e., the C4 pathway.

chapter: WHERE ARE THE ATP AND NADPH USED?
title: C4 pathway
content: Since then CO2 assimilation during photosynthesis was said to be of two main types: those plants in which the first product of CO2 fixation is a C3 acid (PGA), i.e., the C3 pathway, and those in which the first product was a C4 acid (OAA), i.e., the C4 pathway.

title: Ribulose bisphosphate (RuBP)
content: The studies very unexpectedly showed that the acceptor molecule was a 5-carbon ketose sugar – ribulose bisphosphate (RuBP).

title: Carboxylation (Calvin Cycle)
content: Carboxylation – Carboxylation is the fixation of CO2 into a stable organic intermediate. Carboxylation is the most crucial step of the Calvin cycle where CO2 is utilised for the carboxylation of RuBP. This reaction is catalysed by the enzyme RuBP carboxylase which results in the formation of two molecules of 3-PGA. Since this enzyme also has an oxygenation activity it would be more correct to call it RuBP carboxylase-oxygenase or RuBisCO.

title: RuBP carboxylase-oxygenase (RuBisCO)
content: This reaction (carboxylation of RuBP) is catalysed by the enzyme RuBP carboxylase which results in the formation of two molecules of 3-PGA. Since this enzyme also has an oxygenation activity it would be more correct to call it RuBP carboxylase-oxygenase or RuBisCO.

title: Reduction (Calvin Cycle)
content: Reduction – These are a series of reactions that lead to the formation of glucose. The steps involve utilisation of 2 molecules of ATP for phosphorylation and two of NADPH for reduction per CO2 molecule fixed. The fixation of six molecules of CO2 and 6 turns of the cycle are required for the formation of one molecule of glucose from the pathway.

title: Regeneration (Calvin Cycle)
content: Regeneration – Regeneration of the CO2 acceptor molecule RuBP is crucial if the cycle is to continue uninterrupted. The regeneration steps require one ATP for phosphorylation to form RuBP.

title: Bundle sheath cells
content: The particularly large cells around the vascular bundles of the C4 plants are called bundle sheath cells, and the leaves which have such anatomy are said to have ‘Kranz’ anatomy. The bundle sheath cells may form several layers around the vascular bundles; they are characterised by having a large number of chloroplasts, thick walls impervious to gaseous exchange and no intercellular spaces.

title: Kranz anatomy
content: The particularly large cells around the vascular bundles of the C4 plants are called bundle sheath cells, and the leaves which have such anatomy are said to have ‘Kranz’ anatomy. ‘Kranz’ means ‘wreath’ and is a reflection of the arrangement of cells.

title: Hatch and Slack Pathway
content: This pathway (C4 pathway) that has been named the Hatch and Slack Pathway, is again a cyclic process.

title: Phosphoenol pyruvate (PEP)
content: The primary CO2 acceptor is a 3-carbon molecule phosphoenol pyruvate (PEP) and is present in the mesophyll cells.

title: PEP carboxylase or PEPcase
content: The enzyme responsible for this fixation (of CO2 by PEP) is PEP carboxylase or PEPcase. It is important to register that the mesophyll cells lack RuBisCO enzyme.

title: Photorespiration
content: In C3 plants some O2 does bind to RuBisCO, and hence CO2 fixation is decreased. Here the RuBP instead of being converted to 2 molecules of PGA binds with O2 to form one molecule of phosphoglycerate and phosphoglycolate (2 Carbon) in a pathway called photorespiration. In the photorespiratory pathway, there is neither synthesis of sugars, nor of ATP. Rather it results in the release of CO2 with the utilisation of ATP. In the photorespiratory pathway there is no synthesis of ATP or NADPH. The biological function of photorespiration is not known yet.

title: Law of Limiting Factors (Blackman’s Law)
content: When several factors affect any [bio] chemical process, Blackman’s (1905) Law of Limiting Factors comes into effect. This states the following: If a chemical process is affected by more than one factor, then its rate will be determined by the factor which is nearest to its minimal value: it is the factor which directly affects the process if its quantity is changed.
